raw_text:
Downloads enter US singles chart
 
 Digital music downloads are being included in the main US singles chart for the first time.
 
 Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's Boulevard of Broken Dreams is currently number two in Billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year.
 
 Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new Hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the Pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to US radio stations which play chart music. In addition to Green Day, other artists in the current US digital sales top 10 include Kelly Clarkson, The Game and the Killers.
 
 Sales of legally downloaded songs shot up more than tenfold in 2004, with 200 million track purchased online in the US and Europe in 12 months, the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI) reported last month. In the UK sales of song downloads overtook those for physical singles for the first time at the end of last year. The last week of December 2004 saw download sales of 312,000 compared with 282,000 physical singles, according to the British Phonographic Industry. The UK's first official music download chart was launched last September, compiling the most popular tracks downloaded from legal UK sites - including iTunes, OD2, mycokemusic.com and Napster. Westlife's Flying Without Wings - a 1999 track reissued for the occasion - was the first number one of the UK download chart.
 
 A spokesman for the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) said the first combined UK download and sales chart was due to be compiled "within the first half of this year". "Work is going on across the music business right now to make sure the new chart works to plan," he said. The BPI spokesman described the UK music download chart, compiled by the Official Charts Company, as having been "a great success" since its launch. "It has provided a focus for the industry and has really driven interest in downloads among music fans," he said.
llama3.2:1b: Digital downloads are being included in US singles charts starting with the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
Green Day's Boulevard of Broken Dreams is currently number two, while download sales contribute to UK Singles Chart rankings later this year.
llama3.2:3b: Digital music downloads are being included in US singles charts for the first time, with Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporating data from sales of music downloads.
The UK is set to follow suit later this year.
Sales of digitally downloaded songs have increased significantly, with over 10 times more sales reported in 2004 compared to the previous year.
The first combined US and UK charts will also be compiled, with the UK's download chart having been successful since its launch last September.
gemma2:2b: Digital music downloads are being included in the US Billboard Hot 100 chart, alongside physical sales and airplay information, to create the new Hot 100 chart.
This change follows a significant increase in digital song sales, which now surpass physical singles sales in some markets like the UK.
The UK is launching its own combined download and sales chart later this year.

Other artists such as Kelly Clarkson, The Game, and Westlife also entered the charts.
Digital sales data from downloads will be incorporated into the UK Singles Chart later this year.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Digital music downloads are now included in Billboard's Hot 100 singles chart, incorporating sales data previously used only on a separate download chart.
Billboard is expanding its charts to include both physical sales and digital download information starting with the UK singles chart.
This marks a significant shift as sales of legally downloaded songs increased by more than tenfold worldwide in 2004, particularly in Europe and North America.
The inclusion of digital downloads will be used for the Hot 100 chart alongside physical sales and airplay data from US radio stations to create a comprehensive chart format.
Additionally, new charts combining all three sources (physical sales, digital download, and airplay) are being developed for pop music, focusing on American radio stations only.

In UK, downloads surpassed physical singles for first time at end of 2004, with Westlife's Flying Without Wings leading UK download chart.
A combined music download and sales chart is planned for release in early 2005.
